# **Price vs. Quantity** {background-color="#1c4982"}

## ‚ùì Why Not Just Regulate?

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    ‚ÄúIf the government knows the **socially optimal level of pollution**, why not just **mandate** it directly?‚Äù
  </blockquote>
</div>

- **Regulation (quantity control)** has been the **traditional approach**, since it seems straightforward:
  - 1970s: U.S. **limited SO‚ÇÇ emissions** rather than taxing them.  
  - 1987: Global **ban on CFCs** to protect the ozone layer instead of taxing them.

- For **climate change**, however, economists highlight **market-based policies** that use prices or permits to guide behavior.
  - **Carbon taxes** (price-based) and **cap-and-trade** (quantity-based) are the two main policy instruments for reducing GHG emissions.

- Let's examine **when** each‚Äî**price** or **quantity**‚Äîis more effective for achieving climate goals.

## üåç Climate Policy Instruments: The Core Idea

<div style="display:block; margin:5px;"></div>

<div style="font-size:1.9rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **Approach** | **Instrument** | **Mechanism** | **Examples** |
|---|---|---|---|
| <span class="fragment">**Price-based**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Carbon Tax**</span> | <span class="fragment">Sets a **price per ton of CO‚ÇÇ**; firms reduce emissions until <u>*MC = tax*</u>.</span> | <span class="fragment">Sweden CO‚ÇÇ tax; Canada‚Äôs national carbon pricing system</span> |
| <span class="fragment">**Quantity-based (with flexibility)**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Cap-and-Trade**</span> | <span class="fragment">Sets a **cap on total emissions**; firms trade emission permits until<br><u>*permit price = MC*</u>.</span> | <span class="fragment">European Union Emissions Trading System (EU ETS); California‚Äôs Cap-and-Trade Program</span> |

</div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:2rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  Goal: **Achieve climate targets at the lowest total social cost.**
</div>




## üîÑ From Goods to Pollution Reduction

To compare **price** and **quantity** approaches effectively, we must shift focus:

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:2rem;">
  <blockquote>
    From the **market for a product** (like automobile)  
    ‚Üí to the **market for pollution reduction** (like CO‚ÇÇ) itself.
  </blockquote>
</div>


- In basic models, the only way to cut pollution was to **reduce output**.  
- In reality, firms can also **adopt cleaner technologies**:
  - Power plants install **CCUS** to capture CO‚ÇÇ.  
  - Cars use **catalytic converters** to reduce NO‚Çì emissions.

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:2rem; margin-top:1.2rem;">
üëâ  This shift helps us analyze **abatement decisions directly** ‚Äî how firms respond to
  <strong>taxes (prices)</strong> or <strong>caps (quantities)</strong> when multiple reduction options exist.
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-15px;"></div>

<!-- - Set tax **œÑ = MD** (e.g., \$100/tCO‚ÇÇ).   -->
<!-- - Each firm abates while **MC ‚â§ œÑ**, then pays the tax for remaining emissions.   -->
<!-- - **Cost certainty**, **quantity uncertain**; hits **R\*** if MD and MC known.   -->

- Government imposes a **Pigouvian tax (œÑ)** on each unit of pollution equal to its **marginal damage (MD)** ‚Äî for example, \$100 per ton of CO‚ÇÇ.

:::

::::

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>

- Each plant **reduces emissions** as long as its **marginal abatement cost (MC)** is **below œÑ**, and pays the tax on remaining emissions.  
- Once **MC = œÑ**, further abatement would **cost more than the tax**, so the firm stops reducing.

## üìè Quantity Regulation: Mandated Reduction


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="72.5%"}
<div style="text-align: center; width: 100%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/mkt-for-pollution-q.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="27.5%"}

- **Regulation**: Government simply **mandates** that firms reduce pollution by the **optimal amount (R\*)**.


:::

::::

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

::: callout-note
- If **MD is constant**, this is manageable;
  but when **MD declines** with more reduction, the regulator must know **both MD & MC curves** to determine either the **optimal tax** or the **optimal quantity**.

:::

## üè≠ Heterogeneous Plants
<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>

We now consider a case with **two plants** that have **different marginal abatement costs (MC)** ‚Äî a more realistic setting for policy design.

<div style="display:block; margin:10px;"></div>

| **Plant** | **MC** | **Efficient Reduction (example)** |
|---|---:|---:|
| A (newer tech) | Lower | 150 |
| B (older tech) | Higher | 50 |

<div style="display:block; margin:10px;"></div>

- In reality, firms differ in **technology, age, and fuel mix**, leading to **unequal costs** of pollution reduction.  
<!-- - An **efficient policy** must account for these differences ‚Äî the **same total reduction** can be achieved **at lower total cost** if **low-cost firms reduce more** and **high-cost firms reduce less**.   -->
- This setup helps us compare how **quantity regulation (like command-and-control)** and **price-based policies (like a carbon tax & cap-and-trade)** perform under realistic conditions.

<div style="display:block; margin:-25px;"></div>

:::callout-note
- **Command-and-control regulation**: Government **mandates specific pollution reductions** or **sets technology standards** that firms must **follow directly** to control emissions.
:::

<!-- <div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.6rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1rem;"> -->
<!--   ‚öôÔ∏è Real-world efficiency requires **equalizing marginal costs**, not equal reductions. -->
<!-- </div> -->


<!-- - **Equal command-and-control cuts** (100 each) ‚Üí **inefficient**. -->
<!-- - **Tax (œÑ = MD)** or **tradable permits** ‚Üí *A reduces more, B less*, total reduction unchanged, **costs minimized**.   -->

## üè≠ Heterogeneous Plants: Quantity with Flexibility

- The government sets a **total emissions cap** (e.g., 200 permits) and lets firms **trade** them.   
  - Each permit allows **one unit of pollution**. <span class="fragment">(**Coase Theorem!**)</span>

- **A firm will:**
  - **Abate** if its **MC** is **less than the permit price** ‚Üí cheaper to clean than to buy.  
  - **Buy permits** if its **MC** is **greater than the permit price** ‚Üí cheaper to pollute than to clean.  
  - Trading continues until **no further mutually beneficial trades exist** ‚Äî just like in a *Coase bargain*.  

<div style="display:block; margin:-35px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1rem; margin-bottom:1rem; color:#0072B2;">

**MC‚Çê(Q‚Çê) = MC·µ¶(Q·µ¶) = Permit Price = MD <span class="fragment">(= œÑ)</span>**

</div>
<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>


- <u>The result</u>: the **pollution target is met** at the **lowest total cost**,  
  as all firms face the **same marginal cost of abatement**.

## üè≠ Heterogeneous Plants: Summary

<div style="font-size:1.5rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **Policy Type** | **Control Variable** | **Who Decides Reduction?** | **Efficiency** | 
|---|---|---|---|
| **Command-and-control** | <span class="fragment">Fixed **reduction amount** (e.g., 100 each)</span> | <span class="fragment">**Government mandates** cuts</span> | <span class="fragment">‚ùå *Inefficient* if abatement costs differ</span> | 
| **Price Regulation (Tax)** | <span class="fragment">Fixed **price per unit (œÑ)**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Firms choose** abatement</span> | <span class="fragment">‚úÖ *Efficient* ‚Äî firms reduce until **MC = œÑ**</span> | 
| **Cap-and-Trade** | <span class="fragment">Fixed **total emissions cap**</span> | <span class="fragment">**Firms trade permits**</span> | <span class="fragment">‚úÖ *Efficient* ‚Äî firms trade until **MC‚Çê = MC·µ¶ = permit price**</span> | 


</div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:2rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1rem;">
- ‚öñÔ∏è **Command-and-control** is simple but costly.  
- üí° Allowing firms to choose **how much to abate** based on their own costs leads **MCs to equalize across firms**, resulting in an **efficient allocation of abatement**. <span class="fragment">(<u>*Cost-Effectiveness Equimarginal Principle*</u>)</span>
- ‚úÖ **Carbon taxes** and **cap-and-trade** reach the same environmental target **at lower total cost** than uniform regulations.
</div>


<!-- - However, this approach **ignores differences in abatement costs** across firms. -->

<!-- - But it's **inefficient** when plants have **different abatement costs**.   -->
<!-- - A **low-cost plant (A)** can reduce pollution cheaply, while a **high-cost plant (B)** faces steep costs for the same reduction.   -->

## üå´Ô∏è Uncertainty About Costs of Reduction

- So far, we assumed the government **knows the true costs** of pollution reduction.  
- In reality, **marginal abatement costs (MC)** are **uncertain** ‚Äî firms and regulators may not know the exact cost of cutting pollution.  
- Under uncertainty, the **choice between price and quantity instruments** depends on the **shape of the marginal benefit (MD)** curve.

## Price vs. Quantity

- **In Practice:**
  - The instrument choice depends on whether the government wants to get the amount of pollution reduction right or whether it wants to minimize costs to firms.
  - Quantity regulations ensure environmental protection, but at a variable cost to firms, while price regulations ensure the cost to the firms, but at a variable level of environmental protection




## üß† Instrument Choice: What Are We Controlling?

| **Objective** | **Use‚Ä¶** | **Why** |
|---|---|---|
| **Cost certainty** | Carbon Tax | Caps **marginal cost** per ton; quantity flexes. |
| **Environmental certainty** | Cap & Trade / Standard | Hits **emission quantity**; cost may vary. |
| **Both** | Hybrid (price floor/ceiling) | Creates a **price corridor** around a cap. |
